head.title: Devils Aiming to Rise Above Peers

hedline.hl1: Devils Aiming to Rise Above Peers

abstract.p: New Jersey Devils beat Florida Panthers, top team in National Hockey League, 2-0 on Dec 3, and their next six games will be against teams with losing records (M)

block.p: The Devils shut down the top team in the National Hockey League on Tuesday night. Now comes the difficult task: six games against teams with losing records.
It sounds strange, but New Jersey usually does well against the league's elite teams and poorly against mediocre squads.
The Devils shut down the top team in the National Hockey League on Tuesday night. Now comes the difficult task: six games against teams with losing records.
It sounds strange, but New Jersey usually does well against the league's elite teams and poorly against mediocre squads.
Coach Jacques Lemaire is hoping that the trend will change on Thursday night when the Calgary Flames (10-15-2) visit Continental Arena.

The Devils (13-10-1) played effectively in blanking Florida, 2-0, and ending the Panthers' six-game unbeaten streak Tuesday. Lemaire was pleased with Martin Brodeur's performance and with the patience his players showed against a team that uses the same neutral zone trap as the Devils.
''The thing I liked about the game was that we had control with patience and Martin was good,'' Lemaire said today after practice.

Although Brodeur had lost three in a row and was miffed at Lemaire's decision not to play him in Colorado on Saturday against Patrick Roy, his boyhood idol, Brodeur came up with a solid performance against the Florida Panthers, making 28 saves.
Despite turning in his second shutout of the season and 14th of his career, Brodeur is not guaranteed a starting spot against the Flames.
If Lemaire chooses to play Mike Dunham against Calgary, it could erode Brodeur's confidence.

With Dunham having to play in 25 games in order to avoid becoming a Group 6 free agent after the season, goaltending is becoming a delicate matter for the Devils, and Brodeur may have to pay the price.
In the meantime, Lemaire appeared to be more preoccupied with the big picture rather than the goaltenders after practice.

''Everyone talks about how close the teams are,'' Lemaire said, ''and we will have to play better against the rest of the teams in the league. I think we will because we have better balance than in the past.''

The Devils will play host to the Phoenix Coyotes on Friday night. The Coyotes defeated New Jersey last week in overtime. . . . PETR SYKORA (groin) and Steve Thomas (twisted left ankle) will sit out the Calgary game. DAVE ANDREYCHUK (bruised left knee) is expected to play.
